prior_works.title: Robust Estimators in High Dimensions without Strong Assumptions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the modern spectral-filtering framework for adversarially robust mean estimation, whose reliance on the sample covariance (and matrix–vector spectral tests) became the quadratic-in-d runtime bottleneck that this paper circumvents.

prior_works.title: List-Decodable Mean Estimation via Iterative Filtering
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Directly inspired the iterative filtering/spectral outlier-pruning template that underlies robust mean methods later specialized to sparsity; the present work retains this template but redesigns the computations to avoid forming the d×d covariance.

prior_works.title: SEVER: A Robust Meta-Algorithm for Stochastic Optimization
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed that robust pruning via gradient-covariance diagnostics is effective but operationally dominated by covariance computations, highlighting the quadratic-time barrier the current paper explicitly overcomes.

prior_works.title: Learning from Untrusted Data
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the modern adversarial contamination/list-decodable paradigm that motivates spectral filtering for outlier removal, the conceptual backbone the new subquadratic algorithm builds upon.

prior_works.title: Truncated Power Method for Sparse Eigenvalue Problems
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the standard sparse-eigenvector primitive used by prior robust sparse mean estimators on the sample covariance; the new work effectively replaces this covariance-centric instantiation with subquadratic computations.

prior_works.title: Complexity Theoretic Lower Bounds for Sparse Principal Component Detection
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Clarified computational barriers around sparse spectral detection, informing why prior robust-sparse pipelines leaned on explicit covariance and motivating algorithms that simulate sparse spectral tests without materializing d×d matrices.

prior_works.title: Robust Estimation of a Location Parameter
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Formulated the ε-contamination model that is the core problem setting adopted here, framing the goal of estimating a sparse mean under adversarial corruptions.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s subquadratic-time algorithm for robust sparse mean estimation emerges directly from the spectral filtering lineage in modern robust statistics. Foundationally, Huber’s ε-contamination model set the objective, and Charikar–Steinhardt–Valiant crystallized adversarial/list-decodable perspectives that led to spectral filtering as the operative paradigm. Diakonikolas et al. then established and refined the iterative filtering template for robust mean estimation, using covariance-based spectral tests to identify and remove outliers. This methodology (2018–2019) became the practical baseline but incurred a d^2 time bottleneck because it explicitly formed or repeatedly accessed the d×d sample covariance. In the sparse setting, these pipelines typically plug in sparse-eigenvector routines—e.g., the truncated power method—to search for high-variance sparse directions in the covariance, further entrenching quadratic costs. Concurrently, results like Berthet–Rigollet underscored the computational delicacy of sparse spectral detection, explaining the community’s reliance on covariance-centric implementations. SEVER reinforced the same operational pattern in a broader robust-optimization context: covariance-of-gradient diagnostics are powerful yet computationally dominated by quadratic-time steps. The present work preserves the statistical and algorithmic structure of spectral filtering and sparse-direction searches but breaks the d^2 barrier by reengineering these steps to avoid materializing the covariance, enabling subquadratic runtime while maintaining poly(k, log d, 1/ε) sample complexity.
